channel.title: Comments on: Mapping A State Pattern With NHibernate

item.title: By: derick.bailey
item.dc:creator: derick.bailey
item.description:
@Maxim
that's my preferred way passing the parent into the state object.
another possibility is to create a bi-directional relationship between the Order and base State class with an Order property on the state itself. You would need to change the nhibernate mappings to also map this bidirectional relationship, though.
I don't like bidirectional relationships, though, and avoid them whenever i can.

item.title: By: Maxim Tihobrazov
item.dc:creator: Maxim Tihobrazov
item.content:encoded:
Also, how do you use data from Order class in status?

I can imagine something like this:

class Order {
…
Money TotalAmount() { return Status.TotalAmount(this); }
}

class OrderStatus {
…
// we have different approaches for calculating total
abstract Money TotalAmount(Order o);
}

item.title: By: Maxim Tihobrazov
item.dc:creator: Maxim Tihobrazov
item.description: Thank you! I can add that we probably need to lock OrderStatus instances into NHibernate session, so NH will use them instead of creating it's own ones.
